docs.lead_paragraph: MARILEE CRISPINO said she had always dreamed of retiring at age 55. Now it's definite, but hardly as pleasurable a prospect as she had anticipated. She is ''hoping and praying,'' she said, that she can juggle office and home responsibilities until June 9, 2000, when she will quit being an administrative assistant at the New York State United Teachers in Hauppauge and devote her days to caring for her 81-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's disease. Just before Christmas, Ms. Crispino moved her mother, Martha Bryant, from New Harmony, Ind., into a spare room in her home in Centereach after learning that Ms. Bryant had been driving erratically, irrationally contributing to charities and couldn't remember that close relatives had died, nor the neighbors she had known her whole life.

headline.main: The Next Job Perk: Elder Care for Parents

docs.abstract: Article on rising focus on care of aged among Long Island companies as their work forces age and more employees have to care for their elderly parents; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After hauling oats to his cattle before sunrise on the Iowa prairie, Michael Rosmann drives to an office and sits down with farmer after farmer to listen to their troubles. A fourth-generation farmer as well as a clinical psychologist, he speaks the language of men and women on the verge of losing their place on the land. ''These are good people who feel like terrible failures,'' said Dr. Rosmann, who knows what it is to endure sleepless nights spent worrying about crop prices and peril to family tradition. ''Somebody needs to tell them it's not their fault.''

headline.main: As Agriculture Struggles, Iowa Psychologist Helps His Fellow Farmers Cope

docs.abstract: Dr Michael Rosmann, fourth-generation farmer as well as clinical psychologist, knows firsthand desperation that many rural Iowans are facing; that helps him counsel his fellow farmers, whom he visits in fields or at fishing holes, if necessary; map; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE labor shortage created by the strong economy has done more than send Connecticut companies searching for skilled workers. It has also created a labor squeeze in classrooms, forcing schools around the state to scramble for substitute teachers, who can often make more money doing just about anything else. In Norwich, the school system typically had to hire about 15 substitutes a day, but still fell one or two short. So principals or other school staff members took over classes. In Waterford, the schools have needed substitutes 2,725 times this year, but were able to fill only 2,484 positions. New Haven schools needed from 100 to 150 substitutes a day, but often fell 25 to 50 short. The situation has gotten so bad that schools have had to become creative.

headline.main: Help Wanted: Low Salary, No Benefits, Little Respect

docs.abstract: Article on adverse impact strong economy and labor shortage is having in Connecticut schools seeking to recruit and retain substitute teachers; some districts are recruiting parents, firefighters and police officers and recalling retired teachers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH all the scarcity, hysteria, back-stabbing and astronomical prices in the real estate market, it would hardly seem possible for young people just out of college to find apartments. But while apartments go quickly, they can be found, even for those more interested in what they do than in what they earn. Regardless of whether they are making $20,000 a year as editorial assistants or $45,000 (before bonuses) as starting investment bankers, this year's class of graduates will find ways to live in New York, even in Manhattan. But they have to be flexible about where they will live and ruthlessly efficient in their approach. There is no time to think things over, or to get to the bank for a certified check.
docs.abstract: Article on affordable housing in Manhattan and surrounding New York City boroughs for recent college graduates; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Northwest 54th Street in Miami was crowded at 4:30 P.M. on Feb. 7, 1997, and many people saw the three-car collision that killed Detective Robert Vargas. But none of them could help the police determine why he died. The 29-year-old detective, responding in his unmarked car to a robbery call, had what looked to investigators like a relatively minor collision with a Chevy Blazer entering the intersection from his right. His year-old Chevy Lumina skidded across the double yellow line into oncoming traffic and was struck head-on by a Mercury Marquis.

headline.main: Secret Witness To Car Crashes In Black Boxes

docs.abstract: General Motors has installed six million recorders, known as Sensing and Diagnostic Module, into various car models since 1990; device, black box about size of videocassette, records data about car crash when air bag is deployed or almost deployed; newly developed model being installed in hundreds of thousands of GM cars records not only force of collisions and air bag's performance, but also captures five seconds of data before impact; specialists in car crashes say devices could revolutionize some aspects of accident research; photo (M)
